text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- King Hussein and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat discuss taking the Middle East peace process back to its natural course; the monarch affirms his support of Palestinian rights on their national soil.
- Government sources say no changes to be introduced to the election law concerning expanding the number of parliamentary seats from the existing 80.
- Development council discusses the issue of raising cost of water to high-income consumers.

- Crown Prince stresses the need to strengthen bilateral ties with Malaysia during talks with visting Malaysian foreign minister; the two sides discuss setting up joint ventures and activating a dormant higher committee.
- King Hussein reaffirms his total support of the Palestinian people; the monarch is briefed by Arafat on latest developments of the peace process.
- Agriculture Ministry begins to receive compensation applications of farmers whose crops where damaged in the recent cold spell.
- Government ready to supply Palestinian self-rule areas with Iraqi-originated oil if it gets U.N. sanctions committee approval.
- Jordan wants to emulate the Malaysian experience in attracting foreign investments and advancing free-market reforms, officials say.
- Optimism about the expansion of direct foreign investments in Jordan this year.
